channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. Will Lead Talks With Allies on Producing More Weapons
item.description: Defense officials from dozens of countries are set to meet in Brussels to discuss longer-term demand for militaries all over the world.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman reacted to damage to a residential building caused by a missile strike the evening before in Kramatorsk, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Zambia and Its New President Are Still on Their Honeymoon
item.description: Hakainde Hichilema is hailed as a miracle worker for turning around the fortunes of the southern African country. But with his opposition neutralized and a corruption drive focused on his predecessors, some are uneasy.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Gulshan Khan for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Hakainde Hichilema of Zambia.

item.title: Truss Takes a Bold Economic Gamble. Will It Sink Her Government?
item.description: Three weeks into her term, Prime Minister Liz Truss’s financial plans have thrown the markets and Britain’s currency into chaos and put her future in peril.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Support for the Conservative Party, led by Prime Minister Liz Truss, has plunged in the polls.

item.title: Nord Stream Pipeline Breaks Look Deliberate, Europeans Say
item.description: The leaks in the Nord Stream under the Baltic Sea heightened fears of shortages because of the clash with Russia, and showed how vital infrastructure could be at risk.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy

item.title: Tropical Storm Noru Makes Landfall in Vietnam
item.description: More than 800,000 people had been evacuated from central Vietnam before the storm hit the country as a typhoon. It was forecast to dissipate after moving inland.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: Outside an elementary school in Hoi An, Vietnam, that was being used as a shelter during the typhoon on Tuesday.

item.title: For a Deaf Family in Ukraine, War Is a Bewildering Terror
item.description: People with disabilities in the country are often isolated and poor, and for those like Antonina Andriyenko and her daughter, Tanya, the fear and confusion of trying to stay safe is a constant struggle.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Antonina Andriyenko, 74, on the balcony of her apartment in Kharkiv, Ukraine, in July. “We stayed because we didn’t know where to go,” she said.

item.title: Paul Gicheru, Kenya Lawyer on Trial at I.C.C., Is Found Dead
item.description: Paul Gicheru was accused of tampering with witnesses in favor of President William Ruto, whose trial at The Hague collapsed in 2016. The cause of death is not yet known.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: International Criminal Court, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Paul Gicheru, a Kenyan lawyer, at the International Criminal Court in The Hague in February. Kenyan police say that Mr. Gicheru was found dead at his home late Monday.

item.title: Keir Starmer Accuses Liz Truss of Losing Control of Britain’s Economy
item.description: Under the governing Conservatives, the markets are down and the pound is under pressure. On Tuesday, Keir Starmer, the Labour leader, staked his claim as the guardian of sound fiscal policy.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Keir Starmer, the leader of Britain’s opposition Labour Party, used his party conference speech on Tuesday in Liverpool to talk about how his party would try to solve the economic crisis.

item.title: Women in Iran Take Center Stage in Antigovernment Protests
item.description: Women have been casting off their legally required head scarves, forming the primary image of the protests. But grievances against a repressive regime go far beyond the hijab.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Women have been at the center of protests like this one last week in Tehran, defying the mandate to wear head scarves.

item.title: Two Cities, Two Armies: Pivot Points in the Fight in Ukraine’s East
item.description: The battle for the critical Donbas region in Ukraine is centered on two strategically important cities: Lyman, held by the Russians, and Bakhmut, held by Ukraine. The fighting over the cities is fierce as both armies race to claim new ground.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

item.title: 4 Years After Thrilling Cave Rescue, Sleepy Park Readies for Onslaught
item.description: An unheralded national park in Thailand was the center of global attention when 12 boys were trapped in a cave there. In the wake of major movies about the rescue, the park expects a visitor surge.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Luke Duggleby for The New York Times
item.media:description: The entrance to the Tham Luang Cave in Chiang Rai province, Thailand, last month. The rescue of 12 boys and their soccer coach trapped in the cave in 2018 has since become the focus of documentary films and Hollywood blockbusters.

item.title: Iran Strikes Kurdish Opposition Groups in Northern Iraq
item.description: The death of a young Iranian Kurdish woman in police custody has set off an intense wave of protests across Iran over the past 10 days, igniting fury particularly in the country’s Kurdish minority community.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Jane Arraf
item.media:description: Women protesting the killing of Mahsa Amini in Erbil, the capital of the semiautonomous Kurdistan region in northern Iraq, on Saturday.

item.title: Europe Looks at Italy’s Giorgia Meloni With Caution and Trepidation
item.description: Giorgia Meloni, poised to be the country’s first far-right leader since Mussolini, says she supports Ukraine and has moderated her harsh views on Europe, but there are doubts, given her partners.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Giorgia Meloni leaving the polling station where she voted in Rome on Sunday. Her Brothers of Italy received the highest vote total of any single party, according to preliminary results.

item.title: Far From Routine, Asia Trip Presents Thorny Tests for Kamala Harris
item.description: A visit for Shinzo Abe’s controversial state funeral also includes outreach to Asian allies over military advances by North Korea and China.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris on the Howard, a U.S. naval destroyer, at the Yokosuka base in Japan on Wednesday.

item.title: On Portugal’s ‘Bitcoin Beach,’ Crypto Optimism Still Reigns
item.description: In crypto havens such as Meia Praia beach, the confidence in digital currencies remains undimmed even after this summer’s crash.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cardoso for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Bam Bam Beach Bitcoin bar at Meia Praia, a beach in southwest Portugal.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Suspicious gas leaks in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Armed Forces of Denmark, via Associated Press

item.title: As Russians Flee, Some Find Draft Notices Waiting at the Border
item.description: The Kremlin dispatched federal security forces to frontier border crossings packed with Russian men trying to escape the draft by entering countries like Georgia, Kazakhstan and Mongolia.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Andrew E. Kramer and Eric Nagourney
item.media:description: A Georgia-Russia border checkpoint on Monday. Georgia said it would let people enter on foot, and its interior minister said about 10,000 people were seeking entry into the country each day.

item.title: CIA Warned Europe of Potential Attacks on Nord Stream Pipelines
item.description: The warning was not specific, the officials said, and they declined to say whether Russia was identified as a possible attacker.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Karine Jean-Pierre, the White House press secretary, said the Biden administration would not speculate on the cause of the pipeline damage.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia Suspected of Pipeline Sabotage
item.description: Plus a typhoon heads toward Vietnam and a thwarted Chinese attempt to influence U.S. elections.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Lauren Hard

item.title: Prince Mohammed bin Salman Named Saudi Prime Minister
item.description: The crown prince, who has already been the kingdom’s de facto ruler for several years, previously served as deputy prime minister under King Salman, as well as defense minister.
item.dc:creator: AFP
item.category: Khaled bin Salman, Prince of Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia, who has been first in line to succeed his father as king since 2017, was named prime minister on Tuesday.

item.title: Meta Removes Chinese Effort to Influence U.S. Elections
item.description: The parent of Facebook and Instagram said that it had taken down what was the first targeted Chinese campaign to interfere in U.S. politics and that the effort was limited.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: Meta said the Chinese campaign was notable because it did not merely promote the Communist Party’s line.

item.title: Putin Is Expected to Annex Parts of Ukraine After Referendums End
item.description: The staged votes earned broad international condemnation, and world leaders vowed not to recognize the announced results.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: The pro-Russian proxy mayor of Mariupol visited a polling station on Tuesday.

item.title: Turkish Author Ece Temelkuran Sees a Contested U.S. Election Through the Lens of an Attempted Coup
item.description: Ece Temelkuran, a Turkish author, sees parallels between Donald Trump’s claims of election theft and the 2016 attempt to depose Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: The Turkish president Recep Tayyip Erdogan cracked down on dissent after a failed coup attempt in 2016.

item.title: Democracy Under Siege From Autocrats, Social Media and Its Own Failures
item.description: Authoritarianism is on the rise, even in Europe, and the “new world disorder” is messier than a simple fight between democracies and autocracies.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Moscow’s Red Square earlier this month as the city celebrated its 875th anniversary.

item.title: Dating Apps Thrive in China, but Not Just for Romance
item.description: China has cracked down on many tech companies, but has allowed dating apps that provide social connections to flourish.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che and Zixu Wang
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Qu Tongzhou, 28, a Shanghai resident. She recently used dating apps to make friends as she went on a trip to western China.

item.title: An Israel-Lebanon Border Deal Could Increase Natural Gas Supplies
item.description: Offshore gas fields in the Mediterranean could become one of several new energy sources for European countries as they seek independence from Russia.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:description: An Israeli naval vessel patrolling near a production platform in the Leviathan gas field in the Mediterranean Sea off Israel’s northern coast.

item.title: Mete Coban Is Working to Engage Younger Voters in British Politics
item.description: Mete Coban got into politics in his teens. Now, he’s working to encourage a similar drive in young voters.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri
item.media:description: A recent poll showed that 53 percent of young people don’t trust politicians. The councillor Mete Coban aims to change that through his nonprofit, My Life My Say.

item.title: Liberal Politics Needs a Lifeline. Emotion Could Be it.
item.description: A Polish historian and journalist says she believes it is time for liberal politicians to lean harder on emotion the way populists have for years.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri
item.media:credit: Emily Rose Bennett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supplies were at the ready for a gathering of supporters of former President Donald J. Trump in October 2021 outside a restaurant in Holland, Mich., that had been shut down for six months for defying state orders stemming from the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Ban Ki-moon Is Not Leading the U.N. Anymore, but He’s Still Working to Make Change
item.description: The former secretary general of the United Nations is striving to knock down barriers, foster friendship among nations, and campaign for peace and conflict resolution.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri
item.media:description: Ban Ki-moon, center, visiting Bucha, Ukraine in August. He was the United Nations secretary general from 2007 to 2016 and now is the deputy chairman of a group of global leaders known as the Elders.

item.title: Germany Investigates Leaks in Nord Stream Gas Pipelines
item.description: The authorities in Germany, Denmark and Sweden are investigating the cause of leaks in two gas pipelines under the Baltic Sea that caused an abrupt drop in pressure on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Victoria Kim
item.media:description: The land portion of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline in Lubmin, Germany, last week.

item.title: A New Shot Guards Against H.I.V., but Access for Africans Is Uncertain
item.description: An injection every two months rather than a daily pill could shield many more women from the virus, but it is unavailable in places that need it most.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Ihsaan Haffejee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Victoria Makhandule, center, a volunteer with the Treatment Action Campaign, hopes injectable PrEP will soon be available in Soweto, South Africa.

item.title: Wall Street Remains Unsteady After a Painful Stretch for Investors
item.description: Concerns about rising interest rates and the prospects of a global slowdown remain.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Simonetti and Austin Ramzy

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Europe balks at Italy’s rightward turn.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times

item.title: As referendums end, a declaration of Russian annexation is expected to follow.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: A woman in a hospital in the Zaporizka region of Ukraine casting her ballot.

item.title: Cuba Approves Same-Sex Marriage in Historic Vote
item.description: The sweeping 100-page law will also allow same-sex couples to adopt and includes measures that expand protections for women, children and the elderly.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: Electoral authorities counting ballots on Sunday at a polling station in Havana.

item.title: Biden’s Support for Iran Protesters Comes After Bitter Lessons of 2009
item.description: President Biden has quickly backed demonstrators in Iran. When the country faced similar unrest 13 years ago, U.S. officials feared such a strong approach would be counterproductive.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Protests in Tehran last week. The Biden administration has pushed to get satellite systems into the hands of anti-government officials in Iran.

item.title: Russia Admits to Draft Problems as Anger Flares Into Violence
item.description: The Kremlin’s spokesman tried to shift blame for errors in the call-up to regional agencies on Monday, the same day a gunman attacked a draft office in Siberia.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Shashank Bengali and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: Reservists from Tara, in the Omsk region of Siberia, at a recruitment office on Monday.

item.title: White House to Host France’s Macron in Biden’s First State Visit
item.description: After months of pandemic-related disruptions to President Biden’s diplomatic calendar, the White House is set to welcome the French president in December.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden with President Emmanuel Macron of France this year. Mr. Macron’s visit will mark a recovery in relations between Paris and Washington.

item.title: Canada Is Removing Strict Covid-19 Restrictions for Travelers
item.description: After two and a half years, Canada is dropping its remaining restrictions, including testing and quarantine requirements, effective Oct. 1.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:description: All air travelers, regardless of vaccination status, were subject to random coronavirus testing in Canada as recently as March. The country is removing those travel restrictions on Oct. 1.

item.title: US Mountaineer Hilaree Nelson Is Missing in Nepal
item.description: Hilaree Nelson, 49, appears to have fallen into a crevasse on Manaslu while attempting to ski from the summit. Separately, an avalanche killed at least one and left many injured.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Emily Schmall
item.media:description: The summit of Nepal’s Manaslu in 2019.

item.title: Edward Snowden Receives Russian Citizenship
item.description: Mr. Snowden, a former intelligence contractor, left the United States after giving hundreds of highly classified N.S.A. documents to The Guardian and The Washington Post in 2013.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: Edward Snowden speaking during an online forum in Moscow last year.

item.title: Hurricane Ian Could Gain Strength Rapidly. Here’s Why.
item.description: Storms that intensify quickly and unpredictably present a big problem for public safety officials, who have less time to assess threats.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:description: A firefighter in Bourg, La., during Hurricane Ida last year. Wind speeds in the storm rose to 150 miles per hour, from 85 m.p.h., in less than 24 hours.

item.title: Strong Dollar Is Good for the US but Bad for the World
item.description: The Federal Reserve may have no choice but to wage a relentless inflation fight, but countries rich and poor are feeling the pain of plunging currencies.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: When it comes to global finance and trade, the United States has outsize influence.

item.title: Russia’s draft is targeting Crimean Tatars and other marginalized groups, according to activists.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Crimean Tatars marked 75 years since their deportation by the Soviet Union, in Kyiv, in 2019.

item.title: Giorgia Meloni's Election Win in Italy: Here’s What To Know
item.description: Giorgia Meloni, leader of the hard-right Brothers of Italy, looked set to become prime minister after her party garnered more votes than any other.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Giorgia Meloni holding a sign reading “Thank you Italy” at a news conference on Monday. She is almost certain to become Italy’s first female prime minister.

item.title: Meloni Faces Early Test of Italy’s Resolve on Russia and Ukraine
item.description: The hard-right leader Giorgia Meloni has been a full-throated supporter of Ukraine, but her coalition partners have sounded like apologists for Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Giorgia Meloni on Monday after early projections had her coalition winning a majority in Italy’s Parliament. She has unambiguously criticized Russia’s aggression in Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine Honors Slain Soldier Whose Bracelet Made Him a Symbol
item.description: Serhiy Sova, 36, was honored as a Hero of Ukraine by President Volodymyr Zelensky. His body was found in a mass grave in Izium.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Serhiy Sova, whose body was exhumed in Izium earlier this month, in 2019. He was a trainer and breeder of dogs.

item.title: Yevgeny Prigozhin, a Putin Ally, Says He Founded Russia’s Wagner Group
item.description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, a Russian businessman and close associate of President Vladimir V. Putin, confirmed his role weeks after he was seen in a recruitment video for the private military company.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Yevgeny Prigozhin at a meeting of Russian and Turkish government officials and business leaders in Saint Petersburg, Russia, in 2016.

item.title: Iran’s Ferocious Dissent
item.description: Times reporters make sense of what’s happening.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A protest in Tehran last week over the death of a 22-year-old woman, Mahsa Amini, in police custody this month.

item.title: School Shooting in Russia Leaves at Least 15 Dead
item.description: An unidentified gunman entered a school in the city of Izhevsk, killing four adults and 11 children, according to federal investigators.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Police and paramedics working at the scene of a shooting at school No. 88 in Izhevsk, Russia, on Monday.

item.title: Recruitment Officer Wounded in Russian Draft Office Shooting
item.description: A gunman opened fire at a draft office in a Siberian town, in what is believed to be the first attack on a military recruitment center since February to result in serious injury.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Shashank Bengali
item.media:description: Reservists drafted during Russia’s partial mobilization lined up outside a recruitment office in the Siberian town of Tara in the Omsk region on Monday.

item.title: For China’s Auto Market, Electric Isn’t the Future. It’s the Present.
item.description: More electric cars will be sold in the country this year than in the rest of the world combined, as its domestic market accelerates ahead of the global competition.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu
item.media:description: BYD, China’s largest electric vehicle maker, displayed cars at an auto show in Wuhan, China, in July.

item.title: TikTok Seen Moving Toward US Security Deal, but Hurdles Remain
item.description: A draft agreement with the Biden administration to keep the Chinese-owned video app operating in the United States is under review. That could mean more wrangling.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch, David McCabe, Katie Benner and Glenn Thrush
item.category: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.media:description: TikTok has been under a legal cloud in the United States because of its Chinese ownership.

item.title: Monkeypox Appears to Recede, but Risks and Uncertainties Linger
item.description: Scientists do not yet know how well the vaccine and the drug used to treat the infection are working. Two new trials will provide answers.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Workers prepare the Jynneos monkeypox vaccine at a vaccination site in Los Angeles last month. Though cases seem to be receding, recent reports suggest that a single dose may not be protective enough.

item.title: To Defend Democracy, Is Brazil’s Top Court Going Too Far?
item.description: Brazil’s Supreme Court has acted as the primary check on President Jair Bolsonaro’s power. Now many are worried the court is posing its own threat.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and André Spigariol

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Elections in Italy.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: U.S. Warns Russia of ‘Catastrophic Consequences’ if It Uses Nuclear Weapons
item.description: The comments by the national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, illustrate how quickly the rhetoric has intensified as Russia has faltered on the battlefield in recent months.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, this month. American intelligence officials say they still believe the chances that nuclear weapons will be used in the conflict are low.

item.title: Iran Protests Are Fueled in Part by Kurdish Anger
item.description: The protests that have swept Iran following the death of a woman in police custody have been especially intense in the country’s minority Kurdish population.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Protesters in Erbil, the capital of Iraq’s semiautonomous Kurdistan Region, burning an Iranian flag on Saturday.

item.title: Russia Begins Mobilizing Ukrainians to Fight Against Their Own Country
item.description: Panic and fear flooded the occupied territories as Russian forces rounded up men to fight and forced residents to vote in a staged referendum on joining Russia, Ukrainian officials and rights groups said.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A polling station in Mariupol, Ukraine, on Saturday, the second day of a referendum on joining the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic to Russia.
